name: (2-methoxy-phenyl)-acetonitrile
Reason: To predict the melting point of (2-methoxy-phenyl)acetonitrile, we must consider the effects of various functional groups and structural features on the basic unit, which is benzene. The benzene ring has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The methoxy group (-OCH3) generally has a tendency to lower the melting point slightly compared to hydrogen due to its ability to disrupt the crystalline structure; we can estimate this effect to be around -5. The nitrile group (-C#N), on the other hand, due to its electronegativity and linear structure, can increase the melting point through dipole-dipole interaction and possible hydrogen bonding if applicable. We will estimate this increase to be about +10. Lastly, the ethyl spacer (–CH2–) adjacent to the nitrile might provide some additional rigidity, which could slightly increase the melting point; we estimate this effect to be around +2. Summing all these modifications gives us the predicted melting point.

name: (2-methoxy-phenyl)-acetonitrile
Reason: To predict the melting point of (2-methoxy-phenyl)acetonitrile, we should evaluate the influence of different functional groups appended to the basic benzene structure. The base melting point of benzene is approximately 5.5 degrees Celsius. The addition of a methoxy group (-OCH3) to the benzene ring typically has a moderate influence on melting point, but depending on its position and the overall molecular structure, it might provide either a slight increase due to an incremental van der Waals interactions or a slight decrease due to disruption of the crystalline packing; in this situation, we estimate it at approximately +2. The nitrile group (-C#N) is expected to substantially raise the melting point due to its strong dipole and potential for intermolecular interactions, such as dipole-dipole interactions; we estimate this influence to be around +70. Considering these effects together, we subtract the small enhancement from the methoxy group from the substantial increase provided by the nitrile group to speculate an overall change from the benzene baseline.
